{"title":"Section 5, Page 36","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"36
The soundings across Bayou Boeuf, on our line from the east bank, and taken at a ami.
rately low tide, and at nearly equal horizontal distances, were as follows : 4 feet, 8j feet in,
feet, 15 feet, 15 feet, 15 feet, 15 feet, 15 feet, 14 feet, 10 feet; the two extremes being ,-
"iO feet from the banks.
Thence the line continues in the same direction over cultivated land a little more than w
a mile, and enters a palmetto, ash and cypress swamp, having on it but little surface wan,
with very firm clayey bottom, and three feet crevasse water-mark. Crossing this swamp »
a distance of about a half mile, the line enters upon the high lands of Bayou Boeuf agia.
Thence the line passes over said high land, mostly in cultivation, crossing Bayou Raraosm
distance from Lafourche of 22£ miles nearly, and reaches Berwick's Bay at a distance of 3(1
miles from Thibodaux, of which, say 5£ miles is through levee overflowed swamp land, a. ■
the balance on high, level and arable alluvial lands.
On this route there will be required several culverts across small bayous and drains, i«
involving heavy expenditure; and in addition, five bridges—viz.: two across Bayou Tipt,
which is GO feet wide and 8 feet deep ; one across the draining bayou in the swamp betwsa
Bayou L'Ours and Bayou Boeuf, which is 150 feet wide, and from 1 to 3 feet deep ; one at
Bayou Boeuf, the cross section of which is given above; and one across Bayou Ramos, whid
is 360 feet wide, and G feet deep.
The country traversed on this route is very nearly level, no portion being more than 15,
nor less than 2 feet above tide water. Consequently, no cuttings will be required; no
bankments, except in the swamp portions, sufficient to elevate the road above the higheM
crevasse water, and in other portions to secure a good foundation.
About one half of the whole length of the route is on arable land, never overflowed, andlii
other half on land subject to immersion from 1 to 4 feet, in times of extreme high water of the
Mississippi river, caused by breaks of the levee in the parishes of Point Coupee and Vest
Baton Rouge. It might be supposed that an embankment, such as it is proposed to matt
would operate as a dam, causing injury to the lands above it, as well as to the work it*"*
Such would not be the case, because the great area over which this crevasse water extendi,
and the level surface of the country in all directions—mostly a dense forest—gives to theort-
flow more the nature of a lake than that of freshet inundation. The culverts and bridges pi*
posed on the route will be amply sufficient to allow the water to maintain nearly the same le"1
on each side ofthe embankments.
I am in possession of data sufficient to estimate closely on every portion of the road betwef
Thibodaux and Berwick's Bay, with exception only of the bridges. The time allowed W
making the survey was not sufficient to permit me to bore or sound the bottoms of the bay** I
requiring bridges, and consequently only an opinion can be hazarded as to their descripf**
or cost.
Many engineers and others are of opinion that the best manner of building railroads act
overflowed swamps similar to those on this line, is on a construction of tressel work. 1 c°^
ceive that a more substantial and cheaper road-bed can be obtained by throwing up solid
bankments of earth, and I have estimated accordingly, giving them such a height in
swamps as to be more than one foot above the highest crevasse water-marks, and on •
land so high as to secure at all times a solid foundation-
ESTIMATES.
Cutting trees and clearing roadway, --._.. $8,600
All embankments and grading, 36,890
Lumber for mud sills and cross ties, --,... 32,020
Iron rails 63 lbs. per lineal yard, spikes and chairs, - - 112,750
Labor on superstructure, ----....- 32,100
Add 10 per cent, for contingent expenses and engineer's department, 22,236
